Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my phone in one hand, the latest pharmacy newsletter open on the screen. My stepbrother nudged me, grinning as our parents tossed out ideas for the weekend—hiking, a movie, maybe a barbecue. I knew they expected me to join in, to laugh and share my thoughts, to be part of this new family we were all still getting used to. But my mind kept drifting back to the newsletter, to the new drug approvals and the clinical updates I needed to know for work. My manager always reminded us how important it was to stay current, and I didn’t want to fall behind. I tried to split my attention, nodding at my family’s suggestions while scanning the article about a promising new anticoagulant. Guilt twisted in my stomach—if I focused on work, I’d seem distant, but if I joined the conversation, I’d lose precious time to keep up professionally. My stepbrother caught my eye, waiting for my answer about the barbecue, and I felt the pressure mounting from both sides, unsure which expectation I should meet.
